quoteFirst: Twenty-seven trucks were purchased under bid in Wisconsin on March 14. They were inspected and loaded in fourteen cars; the men to operate them were employed and tourist cars furnished for them, following which a train was made up which left Wisconsin at
quoteLast: , on March 16. It arrived at Columbus, N. M., 1,591 miles away, shortly after noon on the 18th; the trucks were unloaded from the cars, loaded with supplies, and sent across the border, reaching General Pershing's command with adequate supplies of food before he had exhausted the supplies taken with him from Columbus."--From the report of Quartermaster-General Henry G.
title: The Railroad Problem
author: Hungerford, Edward, 1875-1948

quoteFirst: On the 16th, the moon rises at 3:45 a. m.; on the 1st, sets at 2:21 a. m., and on the 31st at
quoteLast: On the 4th, at 4:52 p. m., full; on the 11th, at 9:21 a. m., enters upon its last quarter; on the 18th, at 7:23 p. m., new moon; and on the 26th, at 11:46 p. m., enters upon its first quarter.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, October 1884, No. 1
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: ; on the 15th, rises at 4:02, twenty-six minutes before the sun, and sets at 6:36 p. m., some fifty-six minutes earlier than the sun; and on the 30th rises at
quoteLast: , and sets 5:47 p. m. On the 3rd, at 4:00 p. m. he is in conjunction with and about 1° 23′ south of the sun; and on the 21st, at 10:30 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, June 1884, No. 9

quoteLast: Gypo was condemned to death. The three judges went away, leaving Gallagher in charge of the execution of the sentence.
title: The informer
